print.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to produce words, numbers, or pictures on paper, using a machine which puts ink onto the surface
print.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I need to make a few changes before I print the document.
The company’s name was printed in bold letters across the top of the page.
The printer’s switched on but it won’t print.
As a newspaper publisher he understood the power of the printed word (=words that are printed on paper).
print.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: when a computer document prints, a printed copy of it is produced
print.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Press return, then the document should print.
print.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to produce many printed copies of a book, newspaper etc
print.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Over five million copies of the paper are printed every day.
When the book was first written no publisher would print it.
print.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to print a report of something or a letter, speech etc in a newspaper or magazine
print.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: ‘The Express’ was the first paper to print the story.
‘The Telegraph’ has printed numerous articles on this subject over the last three years.
I wrote to the newspaper but my letter wasn’t printed.
print.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to produce a photograph from a photographic film
print.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: It usually takes a couple of hours for the pictures to be developed and printed.
print.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to decorate cloth with a pattern that is put all over its surface by a machine
print.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: a skirt printed with brightly coloured flowers
print.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to write words by hand without joining the letters
print.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Please print your name clearly in the top right-hand corner of the page.
print.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to make a mark on a surface or in a soft substance by pressing something on to it
print.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The mark of the man’s shoe was printed in the mud.
print.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: writing that has been printed, for example in books or newspapers
print.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: There was no print at all on the backs of the tickets.
Very little of his poetry actually got into print  (=was printed).
It must be really exciting to see your work in print.
the pleasure of seeing my name in print
print.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the letters in which something is printed
print.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The book is also available in large print.
The print quality of the new printer is excellent.
print.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a mark that is made on a surface by something that has been pressed onto it
print.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: His feet left deep prints in the soft soil.
print.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: cloth, especially cotton, on which a coloured pattern has been printed
print.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: a lovely selection of floral prints
She was wearing a cotton print dress.
print.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a photograph that has been produced from a film
print.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Why don’t you order an extra set of prints?
print.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a picture that is made by cutting lines onto a piece of metal or wood and then printing it onto paper
print.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: a copy of a painting that is produced by taking a photograph of it and printing it onto paper
print.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to produce words, numbers, pictures etc on paper, using a machine that puts ink onto the surface
print.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The system prints each transaction on the customer’s passbook.
Kodak’s new desktop machine prints16 pages a minute.
The electronic sorters can only read bar codes printed on the lower right-hand corner of letters.
print.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to produce many copies of a document, newspaper, book etc in printed form
print.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: His company lost a contract to print 20,000 temporary auto license tags for Tennessee.
Estonia hired a foreign firm to print banknotes to replace the ruble.
print.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to put a letter, speech, article etc in a book, newspaper etc
print.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: An apology was printed in yesterday’s edition.
print.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: if a computer prints words on a screen, they appear on the screen
print.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: After a delay of four seconds, the translated sentence is printed on a computer screen.
print.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: to write words or letters by hand without joining the letters together, so that they look like the letters in a book
print.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: Print your name at the top and sign the declaration at the bottom of page 2.
print.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: information and news in books, newspapers etc, rather than in other MEDIA
print.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: European services concentrate on print, while in the U.S. the emphasis is on television.
We send information to clients using both print and electronic media.
print.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: if a book is in print, new copies of it are still being printed and it is easily available. If it is out of print, it is no longer being printed
print.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: His small publishing firm has kept classics by American writers in print.
‘Diary of a Nobody’ was published in 1892, and has never been out of print.
print.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: the details in a legal document, contract etc that many people do not take the time to read, but that may have serious effects
print.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: Even cardholders who pay their bills in full are advised to read the small print carefully.
advertisements that display low ticket prices but hide surcharges in the fine print
